title: Why is Portfolio Recovery Associates suing me?
question: I received a letter from an attorney that Portfolio Recovery Associates is suing me for an unpaid debt.
answers:
You can request debt verification. http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/debt-collection-defense-requiring-that-the-collector-document-the-debt.html. If Portfolio refuses, you will have a potential claim against Portfolio for unfair debt collection.

In fact, from your description. even the original letter from Portfolio might have violated the law, since the letter should have already contained the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed. You might want to contact a debt collection attorney to discuss your options.
portfolio recovery associates is a purchased debt buyer which buys delinquent accounts receivables -credit cards- and files suit on them. talk to a local attorney.

In addition to the other answers, Portfolio Recovery has been fined by the Attorney General of New York for filing lawsuits and obtaining judgments on debts that were time barred. You should consult with a knowledgeable bankruptcy and/or debt settlement attorney to review your matter.

Portfolio Recovery is a debt buyer. If you look at the complaint it should list somewhere in it who the original creditor was. However, your statement says you received a "letter". A letter is not a lawsuit. It sounds like they are just threatening to sue, and they will likely get around to it eventually. You can also send them a letter disputing the debt. Do this within 30 days. Look closely at the letter. It may have the warning that if you do not dispute it within 30 days it is assumed to be correct. So, disputing it helps preserve your rights. In that letter demand proof of the debt.
If you did receive a Summons and Complaint then you need to file an answer with the court within 30 days from when you were served.

Hope that helps.
